questions.text: A newborn is examined shortly after birth. The skin shows bluish-gray patches over the sacral area, tiny white cysts over the face, and fine white scaling over the hands and feet. The baby is active, feeding well, and has normal primitive reflexes. There is no fever or other systemic abnormality. What is this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

These are benign, self-limited skin lesions commonly seen in healthy neonates and do not require treatment.

  • Several transient and normal skin findings are commonly observed in neonates and are important to recognize to avoid unnecessary intervention.
  • These conditions typically appear at or shortly after birth, are self-limiting, and have no clinical significance in otherwise healthy infants.
  • In this case:
    • Bluish-gray patches over the sacrum → Mongolian spots
    • Tiny white cysts over the face → Milia
    • Fine white scaling → Desquamation, especially seen in post-term infants
  • These are all part of benign and transient neonatal dermatoses.
  • The baby being active, feeding well, and having normal reflexes further supports that there is no underlying pathology.

Explanation of other options:

Cutaneous candida (Option A): Presents as erythematous papules with satellite lesions, often with systemic signs. Requires antifungal treatment.

Incontinentia pigmenti (Option C): A rare X-linked dominant disorder seen in females. It progresses through vesicular → verrucous → hyperpigmented → atrophic stages and may have neurologic or ocular involvement.

Neonatal lupus erythematosus (Option D): Due to maternal anti-Ro/SSA antibodies, presents with annular erythematous lesions on face/scalp and can have congenital heart block.

choices.text: Both macrosomia and large for gestational age

questions.text: A neonate was born through normal vaginal delivery at term. His birth weight was 3.8 Kg and was plotted on the chart in red, as shown in the figure. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

As seen in the image, the birth weight of the neonate has been plotted on Lubchenco's Chart & since it is above the 90th percentile, he diagnosis is Large for gestational age, LGA Baby. Also, note that since the birth weight is <4 Kg, the baby is not having macrosomia.

  • Classification of neonates based upon centiles/charts (e.g., Lubchenco's or Fenton's Charts); We take BW, Gest Age & then plot on a chart.
  • Interpretation
    • Appropriate for gestational age (AGA): Between 10thand 90th centiles
    • Small for gestational age (SGA): Below 10th centile
    • Large for gestational age (LGA):Above 90th centile

Classification of Neonates Based on Birth Weight (BW)

  • Normal BW: 2.5 to 3.99 kg
  • Low Birth Weight (LBW): Below 2.5 kg
  • Very Low Birth Weight (VLBW): Below 1.5 kg
  • Extremely Low Birth Weight (ELBW): Below 1 kg
  • Macrosomia: 4 kg or above

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2675314/

questions.text: A neonate with erythematous papules with few yellow-white lesions appearing on the trunk on day 2 of life and disappearing in 4 days. The baby is otherwise healthy and normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Erythema toxicum is a benign self-limiting rash in term neonates, typically appearing on day 2–3 and resolving spontaneously within a few days.

  • Erythema toxicum neonatorum (ETN) is one of the most common benign pustular eruptions in term neonates.
  • It presents as erythematous macules, papules, or pustules typically on the trunk, face, and limbs, sparing the palms and soles.
  • It usually appears between 24–72 hours after birth and resolves spontaneously by 5–7 days.
  • The lesions have a characteristic yellow-white pustule on a red base, often mistaken for an infection.
  • However, the infant remains healthy and asymptomatic.
  • A Wright stain of pustule content would show eosinophils, confirming the diagnosis if needed (though it's rarely required).

Explanation of other options:

Mongolian spots (Option B): These are blue-gray pigmented patches usually located on the lumbosacral region, present at birth, and are due to dermal melanocytosis. They are not erythematous or pustular.

Transient pustular melanosis (Option C): Seen in newborns at birth, with pustules that rupture, leaving behind hyperpigmented macules. The lesions lack surrounding erythema, and pigment persists for weeks to months.

Sebaceous hyperplasia (Option D): Small, yellowish-white papules on the nose and cheeks, due to maternal androgens stimulating sebaceous glands. These are not pustular and do not have an erythematous base.

questions.text: Calculate the APGAR score in a neonate at 1 min of life, if there is acrocyanosis, grimacing on examination, HR is 110/min, flexed attitude with spontaneous movements of limbs, and a good cry?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Each parameter of the APGAR score contributes 0-2 points; the total here sums up to 8, with 1 point lost for acrocyanosis.

  • The APGAR score is a rapid assessment tool performed at 1 and 5 minutes after birth to evaluate a newborn's transition to extrauterine life.
  • Each of the 5 criteria is scored from 0 to 2.
  • Scoring in this case:
  • Thus, APGAR score = 1 + 2 + 1 + 2 + 2 = 8
  • Interpretation:
    • 7-10: Normal (no resuscitation usually required)
    • 4-6: Moderate depression (may require resuscitation)
    • 0-3: Severe distress (immediate resuscitation needed)

choices.text: The lesion involves thlower trunk of the brachial plexus, affecting C8-T1 roots
The typical posture is due to involvement of the C5-C6 nerve roots
The condition is known as Klumpke-s palsy and causes claw hand deformity
The affected limb shows increased tone with brisk reflexes

questions.text: A term newborn delivered after a difficult labor presents with an absent Moro reflex on one side. The affected arm is adducted, internally rotated, extended at the elbow, pronated at the forearm, and flexed at the wrist. This posture suggests a brachial plexus injury. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The characteristic "waiter's tip" posture in a neonate with asymmetric Moro reflex is caused by injury to the C5-C6 roots, known as Erb's palsy.

  • In neonatal brachial plexus injury, Erb-Duchenne palsy is the most common type and occurs due to traction injury to the upper trunk (C5-C6 roots), often during difficult or assisted deliveries.
  • The muscles innervated by these roots-deltoid, supraspinatus, infraspinatus, biceps brachii, and brachialis-are weakened or paralyzed.
  • This leads to the classic "waiter's tip" posture:
    • Shoulder adduction and internal rotation (loss of deltoid and infraspinatus)
    • Elbow extension (loss of biceps and brachialis)
    • Forearm pronation (due to unopposed pronators)
    • Wrist flexion (due to gravity and lack of counteraction)
  • The asymmetric Moro reflex is a key early finding in these cases.

Explanation of other options:

The lesion involves the lower trunk of the brachial plexus, affecting C8-T1 roots (Option A): This describes Klumpke's palsy, which causes claw hand deformity, not the upper arm findings seen here.

The condition is known as Klumpke's palsy and causes claw hand deformity (Option C): Incorrect condition-Erb's palsy is being described, not Klumpke's.

The affected limb shows increased tone with brisk reflexes (Option D): This is incorrect-brachial plexus injury leads to flaccid paralysis and decreased tone/reflexes, not spasticity.

questions.text: Which mechanism of phototherapy is chiefly responsible for the reduction in serum bilirubin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Structural isomerization converts bilirubin into a water-soluble form that can be excreted without conjugation in the liver.

  • Phototherapy reduces serum bilirubin primarily through structural isomerization, which involves a permanent change in the structure of unconjugated bilirubin into a water-soluble form (lumirubin) that can be excreted in bile or urine without the need for hepatic conjugation.
  • This is the most effective and dominant mechanism during phototherapy in neonates with hyperbilirubinemia.
  • While other mechanisms like photooxidation and photoisomerization also occur, they play a minor role in bilirubin clearance.
  • Structural isomerization is irreversible and efficient, hence it is the main mechanism responsible for the therapeutic effect of phototherapy.

Explanation of other options:

Photooxidation (Option A): Oxidizes bilirubin into colorless products, but it is a slow and minor pathway.

Photoisomerization (Option B): Involves the formation of cis-trans isomers, but these are reversible and less efficiently excreted.

Conjugation (Option D): Refers to a liver-mediated process (via UDP-glucuronosyltransferase), not related to phototherapy action.

questions.text: After the delivery of an infant of a diabetic mother, the blood glucose of the infant was 60mg/dl. Which other investigation does the sister expect that the physician would ask her to do?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Infants of diabetic mothers are at risk of hypocalcemia along with hypoglycemia due to delayed parathyroid hormone synthesis.

  • In infants of diabetic mothers (IDMs), hypoglycemia occurs due to fetal hyperinsulinemia.
  • During pregnancy, maternal hyperglycemia leads to increased transplacental glucose transfer.
  • In response, the fetal pancreas produces excess insulin, which continues even after delivery, when the glucose supply from the mother stops-this results in neonatal hypoglycemia.
  • In neonates:
    • Hypoglycemia is typically defined as blood glucose <45 mg/dL, although some guidelines may consider <40-45 mg/dL in the first few hours of life as significant.
    • In infants of diabetic mothers, even a glucose level of 60 mg/dL is monitored closely due to the risk of rapid drop.
  • Beyond hypoglycemia, these infants are also prone to other metabolic disturbances, most importantly, hypocalcemia.
  • The cause of hypocalcemia in IDMs is related to:
    • Delayed synthesis and secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH).
    • Suppression of fetal PTH due to maternal hypercalcemia during pregnancy.
    • This can result in early-onset hypocalcemia (within 72 hours of life).

Other common complications of infants born to diabetic mothers include:

  • Macrosomia
  • Birth trauma (e.g., shoulder dystocia, brachial plexus injury)
  • Polycythemia
  • Hyperbilirubinemia
  • Respiratory distress syndrome
  • Cardiomyopathy (especially asymmetric septal hypertrophy)
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hence, after detecting borderline low or low blood glucose, serum calcium is often the next important test in these neonates.

Explanation of other options:

Serum potassium (Option A): Not routinely affected in IDMs unless there's severe acidosis or other specific renal/endocrine issues.

CBC (Option B): May be useful for checking polycythemia, but is not the next most expected investigation in the context of hypoglycemia.

Serum chloride (Option D): Not relevant in the routine evaluation of neonatal hypoglycemia in IDMs.

choices.text: Recommend cessation of breast-feeding for 48 hours and supplement with formula
Wait for 6 hours and retest the serum bilirubin level

questions.text: A 30-hour-old full-term infant has facial and chest jaundice. He is breastfeeding well and has an otherwise normal examination. His bilirubin level is 15.5 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A bilirubin level of 15.5 mg/dL at 30 hours in a full-term infant meets the AAP threshold for initiating phototherapy.

  • In the evaluation and management of neonatal jaundice, the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) provides guidelines based on age in hours and total serum bilirubin (TSB) levels.
  • In a healthy full-term infant, phototherapy is generally indicated when bilirubin levels exceed the treatment threshold for age-specific risk zones.
  • At 30 hours of life, a bilirubin level of 15.5 mg/dL is above the phototherapy threshold for a term infant with no risk factors, as per the AAP phototherapy nomogram.
  • Prompt phototherapy is essential to prevent progression to kernicterus.
  • Since the infant is feeding well, appears otherwise normal, and is not showing signs of acute bilirubin encephalopathy, phototherapy alone is the appropriate next step.
  • Exchange transfusion is not warranted unless the bilirubin is significantly higher (typically >25 mg/dL in term infants or signs of ABE).
  • Waiting to retest without initiating phototherapy would risk bilirubin neurotoxicity in a rapidly rising phase.

Practically, the following cut-offs are often used as a ready reckoner:

  • Age 24 hr-Cut-off of TSB to start PT is 10 mg/dl or more
  • Age 48 hr-Cut-off of TSB to start PT is 13 mg/dl or more
  • Age 72 hr-Cut-off of TSB to start PT is 15 mg/dl or more
  • Age 96 hrand beyond- Cut-off of TSB to start PT is 18 mg/dl or more

Explanation of other options:

Recommend cessation of breast-feeding for 48 hours and supplement with formula (Option A): Not indicated here. Breastfeeding should be encouraged unless there is severe hyperbilirubinemia due to breast milk jaundice (which occurs later, after day 5-7).

Wait for 6 hours and retest the serum bilirubin level (Option C): Delaying treatment in the presence of a high bilirubin level (above threshold) at this age is inappropriate and risks neurological damage.

Consider Exchange Transfusion (Option D): Exchange transfusion is reserved for very high bilirubin levels (>25 mg/dL) or signs of acute bilirubin encephalopathy, neither of which is present here.

questions.text: Neonatal reflex that is not present at birth?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Symmetric tonic neck reflex typically appears after 4-6 months of age and is not present at birth, unlike the other listed primitive reflexes.

  • Neonatal (primitive) reflexes are involuntary motor responses originating from the brainstem and spinal cord, present in newborns and gradually disappear as the cerebral cortex matures.
  • Most primitive reflexes are present at birth and serve as indicators of neurological integrity in early life.
  • However, Symmetric Tonic Neck Reflex (STNR) is an exception-it is a postural reflex that emerges around 4-6 months of age and assists in preparing the infant for crawling.
  • In STNR, when the infant's head is flexed, the arms bend, and the legs extend; when the head is extended, the arms straighten, and the legs bend.
  • This reflex is not seen in the neonatal period, and its presence at birth would be abnormal.

Table: Neonatal Reflexes

questions.text: Asymmetric Moro's reflex is seen in all of the following conditions, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypoglycemia is a metabolic disturbance and does not cause focal neuromuscular asymmetry like that seen with an asymmetric Moro reflex.

  • The Moro reflex is a primitive neonatal reflex normally present at birth and typically symmetrical.
  • When it appears asymmetric, it usually indicates a localized neurological or musculoskeletal injury on one side of the body.
  • This asymmetry is clinically significant and suggests impairment in one upper limb due to either nerve injury, fracture, or neurological condition affecting only one side.
  • Asymmetric Moro reflex can be seen in:
    • Erb's palsy (C5-C6 injury): Due to shoulder dystocia or traction during delivery, resulting in a flaccid arm on the affected side. (Option B ruled out)
    • Fracture clavicle: Common during difficult vaginal deliveries, leading to pain and non-use of the affected limb. (Option D ruled out)
    • Spastic hemiplegia: A form of cerebral palsy with early asymmetric tone and reflexes. (Option A ruled out)
  • However, hypoglycemia is a systemic metabolic condition, and though it may cause jitteriness or seizures, it does not cause unilateral reflex suppression; hence, it is not associated with asymmetric Moro reflex.

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in anterior fontanelle formation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lambdoid suture is located posteriorly and is involved in the formation of the posterior fontanelle, not the anterior one.

  • The anterior fontanelle is the largest in the infant skull, diamond-shaped, and located at the junction of several cranial sutures.
  • It is a soft, membranous gap where multiple bones and sutures meet, allowing for skull expansion during brain growth.
  • Bones and sutures forming the anterior fontanelle:
    • Frontal bone (divided by the metopic suture) (Option A ruled out)
    • Parietal bones (joined by the sagittal suture) (Option D ruled out)
    • Frontal and parietal bones (joined by the coronal suture) (Option B ruled out)
  • The lambdoid suture, however, is located between the parietal bones and occipital bone at the back of the skull and contributes to the posterior fontanelle, not the anterior one.
  • Thus, it is not involved in anterior fontanelle formation.

questions.text: A baby receiving KMC is now stable enough for the procedure to be stopped. What shall be the baby's weight at which you shall decide to stop KMC?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Kangaroo Mother Care is usually discontinued once the infant reaches a weight of >2500 grams, maintaining stable vital signs and feeding well.

  • Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) is a method of care for low birth weight (LBW) and preterm infants, involving skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, and early discharge.
  • It improves thermoregulation, breastfeeding, bonding, and survival.
  • Discontinuation Criteria for KMC:
    • Baby weighs >2500 grams
    • Maintains normal temperature without support
    • Shows consistent weight gain
    • Has good feeding ability (preferably direct breastfeeding)
    • Exhibits stable respiration and heart rate
    • No signs of infection or instability
  • Thus, the baby is considered physiologically mature enough to maintain homeostasis and normal growth without continuous skin-to-skin contact.
  • Often this is desirable until the baby's gestationreaches term or the weight is around 2500 g.
  • Once the weight cut-off is reachedor crossed and the neonate starts wriggling to show that she is uncomfortable, pulls her limbs out, cries, and fusses whenever put in skin-to-skin contact, the mother can wean the baby from KMC.

Explanation of other options:

>1500 grams (Option A): Too early. The baby is still considered very low birth weight (VLBW); KMC should be continued.

>2000 grams (Option B): Still premature to stop. Continued KMC offers benefits until at least 2500 g.

>3000 grams (Option D): KMC can be safely stopped before this weight, as 2500 g is the standard cutoff.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Supplementary nutrition is not a component of KMC, which emphasizes exclusive breastfeeding, not formula or supplemental feeds.

  • Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) is a proven intervention for improving outcomes in low birth weight and preterm infants, especially in resource-limited settings.
  • It consists of three core components:
    • Skin-to-skin contact: Continuous or intermittent skin-to-skin positioning of the infant on the caregiver's chest (usually mother), helping in thermoregulation, bonding, and stability. (Option A ruled out)
    • Exclusive breastfeeding (EBF): Encouraging direct breastfeeding or expressed breast milk without additional supplements. (Option B ruled out)
    • Early discharge with proper follow-up: Once the baby gains adequate weight and stability, discharge is done with structured follow-up to monitor growth and health. (Option D ruled out)
  • Supplementary nutrition, such as formula or fortified milk, is not a standard part of KMC and is only introduced if exclusive breastfeeding is not possible due to medical reasons.
  • KMC is particularly encouraged to promote exclusive maternal lactation.

In the latest AIIMS Protocol 2023, 3rd Edition, a 4th component called Continued follow-up has been mentioned.

questions.text: Identify the gestational age during which feeding of the baby is mostly administered using the instrument shown in the picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a paladai, a traditional feeding utensil used for neonates. Paladai is used for oral feeding in preterm neonates primarily between 32 and 34 weeks of gestation due to developing but immature suck–swallow coordination.

  • The paladai is a traditional utensil commonly used to feed neonates who are unable to breastfeed directly.
  • It is especially useful for preterm neonates who have partially developed but uncoordinated feeding reflexes.
  • Neonatal feeding approach depends on gestational age and the maturation of the following reflexes:
    • Rooting reflex: Appears at ~32 weeks
    • Sucking reflex: Begins to develop at 28 weeks and matures around 34 weeks
    • Swallowing reflex: Begins at 28 weeks, matures at 32–34 weeks
    • Suck–swallow–breath coordination: Typically matures between 34–36 weeks
  • In neonates between 32–34 weeks, while the sucking and swallowing reflexes are present, the coordination is still immature.
  • Thus, feeding using a paladai helps safely deliver milk with controlled flow, preventing aspiration.
  • For extremely preterm infants (<32 weeks), gavage feeding (via orogastric or nasogastric tubes) is preferred due to immature reflexes.
  • Once the baby reaches ≥34 weeks and demonstrates coordinated suck-swallow-breathe patterns, direct breastfeeding or bottle feeding becomes more feasible.
  • Feeding of LBW & preterm meconates depends on Gestational Age
    • <28 Week→ IV fluids/TPN (Option A ruled out)
    • 28 - 31 weeks→ Tube feeds (Nasogastric/or gastric) (Option B ruled out)
    • 32 - 34 weeks → Spoon feeds/Katori/Paladai feeds
    • >34 week→ Breast feeds (OptionD ruled out)

Reference: 

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4815378/

questions.text: A preterm neonate could not be started on the mother's feed due to some maternal issues. Which among the following is the best alternative to administer in such a case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When mothe's milk is unavailable, donor human milk is the next best option for preterm neonates due to its immunologic and nutritional superiority.

  • Breast milk is the ideal nutrition for all neonates, especially preterm infants, as it provides essential immunological factors, growth factors, and nutrients.
  • However, when a mother's milk is not available or insufficient, the best alternative for a preterm neonate is pasteurized donor human milk from a human milk bank.
  • Donor human milk retains many of the protective components of mother's milk, even after pasteurization, and significantly reduces the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), which is a major concern in preterm infants.
  • This is why all major guidelines, including those by the WHO and AAP, recommend donor milk over formula for preterm babies when mother's milk is not accessible.
  • Formula milks (term or preterm) lack immunologic benefits and have a higher risk of feeding intolerance and NEC in preterm neonates.
  • Cow's milk is inappropriate for neonates altogether due to its high renal solute load, risk of allergy, and nutritional imbalance.

DONOR HUMAN MILK:

  • Donor human milk [DHM]is the milk expressed and voluntarily donated by lactating women other than the biological mother of the recipient baby.
  • This donor human milk is pasteurized using the Holder pasteurization method[pasteurized donor human milk; PDHM] and dispensed for the use of the recipient.
  • Donation should be free and without any monetary benefit.
  • The recipient should also be provided the DHM free of cost.
  • World Health Organization [WHO]and National Neonatology Forum [NNF], India recommends DHM as the preferred choice if mother's milk is not available for feeding of preterm or low- low-birthweight [LBW] infants, including very preterm [<32 weeks' gestation] or very LBW [<1.5 Kg] infants.

Explanation of other options:

Preterm formula milk (Option A): Though nutritionally tailored for preterm babies, it lacks the immune-protective components of human milk and increases the risk of NEC.

Term formula milk (Option B): Inferior to preterm formula in nutritional content for preterms and similarly lacks protective immunological benefits.

Cow's milk (Option D): Not suitable for any neonate, especially preterm, due to the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, allergy, and high solute load.

questions.text: All are true about human colostrum EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Colostrum is low in sugar (especially lactose) compared to mature milk.

  • Colostrum is the first milk secreted in the initial 2–4 days postpartum.
  • It is thick, yellowish, and produced in small amounts, but is rich in proteins (especially IgA) and minerals.
  • It plays a crucial role in neonatal immunity and gut maturation.
  • Sugar (lactose) content is low in colostrum, unlike mature milk.
  • Foremilk, secreted at the start of a feed, is watery and has moderate lactose.
  • Hindmilk, secreted later in the same feed, is rich in fat and lactose (high sugar).
  • Hence, colostrum differs from foremilk and hindmilk by having low sugar.
  • Colostrum is thick and yellow due to high protein and carotenoid content. (Option A ruled out)
  • Colostrum is rich in secretory IgA, providing passive immunity to the neonate. (Option B ruled out)
  • It contains high levels of amino acids, sodium, chloride, magnesium, and zinc. (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: HR <60/min with Chest Compressions & PPV for 30 sec
HR <60/min with Chest Compressions & PPV for 60 sec

questions.text: A term neonate is being resuscitated in the delivery room. After 30 seconds of effective positive pressure ventilation (PPV), the heart rate remains below 60/min, so chest compressions are initiated. After 60 seconds of coordinated chest compressions and effective PPV, the heart rate is still below 60/min. In which of the following scenarios should epinephrine be administered?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Epinephrine is indicated when the heart rate remains <60/min after 60 seconds of effective PPV and coordinated chest compressions, and should be given via intravenous or intraosseous route.

  • According to the Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) 8th edition, epinephrine is administered only when the heart rate remains <60 beats per minute after:
    • At least 30 seconds of effective positive pressure ventilation (PPV), followed by
    • At least 60 seconds of coordinated chest compressions with continued effective PPV and 100% oxygen.
  • This delay allows time to correct hypoxia-induced bradycardia, which is the most common cause in neonates.

Epinephrine Dose in Neonates:

  • Preferred Route: Intravenous (via umbilical venous catheter)
  • IV Dose: 0.01–0.03 mg/kg per dose
  • This is equal to 0.1–0.3 mL/kg of the 1:10,000 concentration (0.1 mg/mL)
  • Endotracheal (ET) Route (if IV access not available): Dose may be higher (0.05–0.1 mg/kg), but less effective and not preferred
  • Repeat every 3–5 minutes if the heart rate remains <60/min despite ongoing resuscitation.
  • Administering a higher dose than recommended (e.g., 0.1 mg/kg IV) has been associated with worse outcomes, including hypertension, tachyarrhythmias, and intracranial hemorrhage.

Neonatal Resuscitation

Explanation of other options:

HR <100/min with PPV for 30 sec (Option A): This is too early for epinephrine; continue PPV and reassess.

HR <60/min with PPV for 60 sec (Option B): If compressions haven’t been started yet, they should be; epinephrine is still not indicated without chest compressions.

HR <60/min with Chest Compressions & PPV for 30 sec (Option C): Too early; epinephrine is not given before 60 seconds of coordinated compressions and PPV.

questions.text: A newborn was born at term and did not cry after birth. Resuscitation was started, and the baby was connected to an ECG and SPO2 monitor at 3 minutes of life. Which limb is usually preferred for accurate pre-ductal SpO2 measurement in such a neonate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The right upper limb reflects pre-ductal oxygen saturation, as it receives blood supply directly from the aortic arch before the ductus arteriosus.

  • In neonates, pre-ductal SpO2 monitoring is critical during the initial minutes of life, especially during resuscitation.
  • The ductus arteriosus is a fetal shunt connecting the pulmonary artery to the descending aorta.
  • After birth, it begins to close but may remain patent for a short while.
  • Therefore, oxygen saturation can vary before (pre-ductal) and after (post-ductal) the ductus.
  • The right upper limb (usually right hand or wrist) is supplied by the brachiocephalic trunk, which arises before the origin of the ductus arteriosus from the aortic arch → this is pre-ductal blood.
  • Lower limbs and left upper limb may reflect post-ductal blood oxygen levels depending on ductal flow, hence are less reliable during early resuscitation. (Options A, B, D ruled out)

choices.text: Intubate with an endotracheal tube and suction meconium from the trachea

questions.text: A full-term infant born through emergency cesarean section to a 34-year-old mother whose pregnancy was complicated by hypertension and abnormal fetal heart monitoring. At delivery, she is limp, apneic, and bradycardic. Which of the following is the best first step in resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Initiating positive pressure ventilation (PPV) is the first and most effective step in resuscitating a neonate who is apneic and bradycardic.

  • In neonatal resuscitation, the most critical intervention for a newborn who is not breathing (apneic) or has a heart rate <100 bpm is positive pressure ventilation (PPV).
  • According to the NRP (Neonatal Resuscitation Program, 8th edition), bag-and-mask ventilation should be initiated within the first 60 seconds of life (the"Golden Minute") when the newborn shows signs of ineffective breathing or bradycardia.
  • This step improves oxygenation and helps increase the heart rate.
  • The mother's risk factors (hypertension, abnormal fetal monitoring) suggest perinatal hypoxia.
  • In such neonates, effective PPV is often life-saving and takes priority over other steps like chest compressions or advanced airway management, which come only if HR remains <60 bpm after 30 seconds of effective PPV.

Explanation of other options:

Administer IV bicarbonate (Option A): Not a first-line intervention; used only in prolonged resuscitation when there is metabolic acidosis, and even then cautiously.

Only chest compressions without PPV (Option B): Chest compressions are not started unless HR remains <60 bpm after 30 seconds of effective PPV.

Intubate with an endotracheal tube and suction meconium from the trachea (Option D): Routine suctioning for meconium-stained liquor is no longer recommended unless there are clear signs of airway obstruction and meconium is visualized. In this case, there's no mention of meconium-stained amniotic fluid.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best way to assess adequate response of ventilation during neonatal resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An increase in heart rate is the most reliable and earliest sign of effective ventilation in neonatal resuscitation.

  • During neonatal resuscitation, the primary goal is to ensure adequate oxygen delivery to vital organs, especially the brain and heart.
  • In the majority of cases, positive pressure ventilation (PPV) alone is sufficient to revive an apneic or bradycardic newborn.
  • According to the Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) 8th edition, the most important indicator of effective ventilation is a rising heart rate, as it reflects improved oxygenation and perfusion.
  • If the heart rate does not improve, ventilation should be reassessed and corrected immediately (e.g., using MR SOPA steps).
  • Other parameters like chest rise and oxygen saturation are helpful supportive indicators, but heart rate is the key physiological marker of resuscitation effectiveness.

Explanation of other options:

Adequate Chest Rise (Option A): Indicates that air is entering the lungs, but does not confirm adequate gas exchange or systemic improvement.

Auscultation showing equal air entry (Option C): Useful to ensure bilateral ventilation, but not a reliable indicator of adequate resuscitation response.

Checking SpO2 (Option D): Oxygen saturation improves slowly and may lag behind heart rate; not the first or most reliable parameter to guide immediate response.

questions.text: A neonate delivered at term did not cry immediately at birth. Initial Steps were performed, and the child's HR was found to be 88/min. What is the immediate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A heart rate below 100/min after initial steps indicates ineffective breathing and mandates positive pressure ventilation (PPV).

  • According to the Neonatal Resuscitation Protocol (NRP):
    • Initial steps include warming, positioning the airway, clearing secretions (if needed), drying, and stimulating the baby.
    • If, after these steps, the heart rate is <100/min, the next priority is ventilation, since inadequate breathing is the most common cause of bradycardia in neonates.
    • Positive pressure ventilation (PPV) helps improve oxygenation and ventilation and usually leads to an increase in heart rate.
    • If heart rate falls below 60/min despite 30 seconds of effective PPV, then chest compressions (CPR) are started, followed by epinephrine if there is no improvement.

Explanation of other options:

Start O2 (Option A): Oxygen alone is insufficient when the heart rate is <100/min. PPV is the priority, not just oxygen.

Start CPR (Option B): CPR is indicated only if HR is <60/min after 30 seconds of effective PPV.

Give Epinephrine (Option D): Epinephrine is only indicated if HR remains <60/min despite both PPV and CPR. It is not the first step at HR 88/min.

choices.text: Intubate, give PPV and start chest compressions
Intubate, give PPV, start chest compressions and give Epinephrine

questions.text: A neonate delivered at term did not cry or breathe at birth. Initial Steps were performed, and the child's HR was found to be 40/min. What is the immediate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Heart rate <60/min after initial steps requires bag-mask ventilation (BMV) with room air as the immediate next step in term neonates.

  • According to NRP guidelines, in a non-breathing term neonate with HR <60/min after initial steps, the priority is effective ventilation using bag-mask ventilation (BMV) with room air.
  • Oxygen concentration:
    • For term neonates, start BMV with room air (21% O2).
    • For preterm neonates (<35 weeks), BMV is initiated with 21-30% O2, and adjusted as per SpO2.
  • SpO2 targets (preductal, i.e., right hand):
    • 1 min: ~60-65%
    • 3 min: ~70-75%
    • 5 min: ~80-85%
    • 10 min: ~85-95%
  • Increasing oxygen concentration or advancing to chest compressions or medications is only considered after at least 30 seconds of effective ventilation, if the HR remains <60/min.

Explanation of other options:

Start BMV on 100% O2(Option B): Term neonates do not require 100% oxygen initially. Starting with room air reduces oxidative stress and is preferred unless there's no improvement.

Intubate, give PPV, and start chest compressions (Option C): Chest compressions are started only if HR remains <60/min despite 30 seconds of effective BMV. Intubation may be considered later for ineffective mask ventilation.

Intubate, give PPV, start chest compressions, and give Epinephrine (Option D): This step is too premature. Epinephrine is reserved for when HR is <60/min after 30 seconds of BMV + 60 seconds of chest compressions.
